Carmen tiene 27 años de edad vive en el cantón San Miguel provincia de Bolívar su estado civil es casada vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos de 10, 7 y 5 año.
Es integrante de la ventanilla Ambrocio Laso que se dedican a las labores agrícolas.
  
Carmen se dedica a la agricultura y siembra Papas, utilizara el dinero del crédito para la compra de insumos agrícolas con el apoyo del crédito puede comprar lo que sea necesario para la siembra de las papas. El realiza las compras en la ciudad de Chimbo todas las semanas, su sueño es seguir unido con su familia y ser muy feliz enfrentara los desafíos que se le presente en la vida. En los tiempos libres se dedica a la fundación de la comunidad y a ver la television.
texts.en:
Carmen is 27 years old. She lives in the San Miguel canton in the Bolívar province. She is married and lives with her husband and their three children, who are 10, 7, and 5 years old.  She is a member of the Ambrocio Laso communal bank, whose members work in agriculture.
  
Carmen works in agriculture and grows potatoes.  She will use the money from the loan to purchase agricultural supplies. With the support of the loan, she will be able to purchase the necessary things to grow potatoes.

She makes her purchases in the city of Chimbo every week. Her dream is to continue to keep her family together and be very happy, even while facing the challenges that life presents.

In her free time, she likes to spend time at the community foundation and watch television.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf is a dedicated farmer from Kaduna State. As a Babban Gona member, Yusuf  is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yusuf can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yusuf is ambitious and is aiming to reap a total of 90 bags this season on his 1.80ha field. When asked, Yusuf said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland." With this loan, Yusuf is on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La socia Juana vive en la hermosa ciudad de Challabamba y continua dedicándose a la agricultura, la socia lleva buen tiempo dedicándose a este negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia siembra lo que son papa, trigo entre otros, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas, abono entre otros.
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “Sol Naciente de Mojopata”. 
La socia agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales con mucha responsabilidad. (La comunidad Mojopata está ubicado en distrito de la Challabamba de la provincia de Paucartambo, Cusco, Perú).
texts.en:
Juana lives in the beautiful city of Challabamba and continues to work in agriculture. She has worked for good amount of time in this business which is going well for her thanks to her dedication each and every day. She plants potatoes and wheat, among other things. She would like to be able to keep working to continue supporting her family. 

She is asking for the loan to buy seeds and fertilizer, among other things. She belongs to the communal bank “Sol Naciente de Mojopata”. She is grateful and values the loan. She has agreed to comply with the monthly payments with responsibility. (The Mojopata community is located in the Challabamba district in the province of Paucartambo in Cusco, Perú).

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer, among other things.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La socia Juana se siente contenta por el apoyo del crédito pues le ayudo mucho con el negocio y le fue muy bien, la socia Juana continua  dedicándose al negocio de crianza de animales menores como cuyes y chanchos, la socia lleva buen tiempo con su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeños que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de cuyes para su negocio.
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “Sol Naciente de Mojopata”.
Agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales con mucha responsabilidad. (La comunidad Mojopata está ubicado en distrito de la Challabamba de la provincia de Paucartambo, Cusco, Perú).
texts.en:
Juana is very happy to have had the support of the previous loan because it helped her with her business and went very well. Juana continues to work at her business, where she raises small animals like guinea pigs and pigs. She has been working in her business for a long time and it is going well due to the effort that she puts forth every day. She hopes to continue working so that she can support her family. 

She requests the loan so that she can purchase guinea pigs for her business. She belongs to the Sol Naciente de Mojopata Communal Bank. She is thankful for the loan and appreciates it, and promises to make her monthly payments in a responsible manner.

The community of Mojopata is located in the Challabamba district in the province of Paucartambo, Cusco, Perú.

loans.use: to purchase guinea pigs for her business.

loans.name: Ana Lucia

texts.es:
Ana tiene 31 años de edad vive en el cantón San Miguel provincia de Bolívar su estado civil es casada vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos de 6, 3 y 2 año.
Es integrante de la ventanilla Ambrocio Laso que se dedican a las labores agrícolas.
  
Ana se dedica a la agricultura y siembra Papas, utilizara el dinero del crédito para la compra de insumos agrícolas con el apoyo del crédito puede comprar lo que sea necesario para la siembra de las papas. El realiza las compras en la ciudad de Chimbo todas las semanas, su sueño es comprarse un carro para poder salir a vender el producto que cosecha, enfrentara los desafíos que se le presente en la vida. En los tiempos libres se dedica a la fundación de la comunidad y a tejer.
texts.en:
Ana is 31 years old. She lives in the San Migues canton in the Bolívar province. She is married and lives with her husband and their three children, who are 6, 3, and 2 years old. She is a member of the Ambrocio Laso communal bank, whose members work in agriculture.
  
Ana works in agriculture and grows potatoes. She will use the loan to purchase agricultural supplies. With the support of the loan, she will be able to purchase what she needs in order to grow potatoes.

She makes her purchases in the city of Chimbo every week. Her dream is to purchase a car so that she can use it to sell the products that she harvests. She faces many challenges in life. In her free time, she spends time at the community foundation and sews.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Champey's Group

texts.en: Champey is 25 years old and a local resident from Bovel district of Battambang province. She has two children who are too young for schooling. To overcome the need in her household, she grows cassava, maize, soybean, and rice as the main sources of income, and works for others for a fee. Besides her business loan, she and her co-borrower are getting a consumption loan. Champey, who also acts as the group leader, will spend her entire loan portion to buy household appliances for her family. She highly believes that she can gain a good yield, better than before.

loans.use: To buy household appliances for her family

loans.name: Dabo

texts.en: Dabo is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Dabo joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Rusili, Hayatu and Zilani. Dabo is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Dabo will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Dabo can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Dabo said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Dabo is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Ayuba Jalawa

texts.en: Ayuba Jalawa is a 40-year-old farmer from Jalawa.  As a Babban Gona member, Ayuba Jalawa is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ayuba Jalawa can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Ayuba Jalawa is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Ayuba Jalawa said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children: Rahama, Ra'uf, and Kabiru, and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en:
Lubov is in the flower business. She raises flowers in a greenhouse and then sells them at the market. She has been in this business for 10 years. She enjoys her flower business very much. The many repeat clients who buy flowers from Lubov every year are the key to her successful business.

The last time Lubov used Kiva, she needed a loan for business purposes. This time, Lubov needed to fix her house, and she decided to get another loan. Lubov needs to fix two rooms in her house and change floors, windows, electrical, etc. She is requesting a loan of 40,000 UAH.

loans.use: to fix two rooms in her house

loans.name: Fortunato

texts.es:
El socio Fortunato vive en la comunidad de Mojopata ,el socio continua trabajando en una entidad del estado en área de administración como asistente, él socio lleva buen tiempo trabajando para dicha entidad el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, el socio pertenece al banco comunal “Sol Naciente de Mojopata”.
El socio solicita el crédito para los estudios de sus hijos.
El socio agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales con mucha responsabilidad. (La comunidad Mojopata está ubicado en distrito de la Challabamba de la provincia de Paucartambo, Cusco, Perú).
texts.en:
Fortunato lives in the community of Mojopata. He continues to work for a government administration business as an assistant. He has been working her for a long time and it is going well due to the effort that he puts forth every day.

He belongs to the Sol Naciente de Mojopata communal bank. He requests the loan to pay his children's school tuition. He is thankful for the loan and appreciates it, and promises to make his monthly payments in a responsible manner.

Mojopata is located in the district of Challabamba in the province of Paucartambo, Cusco, Perú.

loans.use: to pay his children's school tuition.

loans.name: Maria Lorenza

texts.es:
Maria tiene 41 años de edad vive en el cantón San Miguel provincia de Bolívar su estado civil es casada vive con su esposo y sus 6 hijos.
Es integrante de la ventanilla Ambrocio Laso que se dedican a las labores agrícolas.
  
Maria se dedica a la agricultura y siembra Papas, utilizara el dinero del crédito para la compra de insumos agrícolas con el apoyo del crédito puede comprar lo que sea necesario para la siembra. Ella realiza las compras en la ciudad de Chimbo todas las semanas, su sueño es seguir unido con su familia y ser muy feliz enfrentara los desafíos que se le presente en la vida. En los tiempos libres se dedica a la fundación de la comunidad.
texts.en:
Maria is 41 years old. She lives in the San Miguel canton in the province of Bolívar. She is married and lives with her husband and their 6 children. She is a member of the Ambrocio Laso communal bank, whose members work in agriculture.

Maria works in agriculture and grows potatoes. She will use the loan to purchase agricultural supplies. With the support of the loan, she will be able to purchase the necessary items to grow potatoes. She makes her purchase in the city of Chimbo every week.

Her dream is to continue moving forward with her family and to be happy in the face of challenges presented in life. In her free time, she spends time at the community foundation.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en: Fe finds pleasure in making snacks. She is thankful that she earns well, too, from this. She seeks help from PMPC on the needed capital for her snack vending business. Recently, her production increased, and she needs more raw ingredients like flour, sugar, milk and butter. PMPC approved her needed capitalization. She hopes to accept catering services in the near future.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients like flour, sugar, milk and butter

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal SOLIDARIDAD TAMBO REAL, él socio continua dedicándose a la ganaderia,el socio lleva años de dedicándose al negocio  de ganadearía el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, él socio desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
El socio solicita el crédito para la compra de una vaca.

 El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en: Mario belongs to the "SOLIDARIDAD TAMBO REAL" communal bank. He continues to work raising livestock. He has been raising livestock for years and things are going well for him thanks to the determination he brings to his work each day. He wants to continue to work in this manner to continue to support his family. He is requesting a loan to buy a cow. He is happy with the loan and promises to comply with the payments of his installments.

loans.use: to buy a cow.

loans.name: Cirila

texts.es:
La socia Cirila pertenece al banco comunal SOLIDARIDAD TAMBO REAL, la socia continua dedicándose a la  ganadería y agricultura, la socia lleva años dedicándose a sus negocio los cuales le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a sus negocio, la socia cultiva lo que son papa y maíz, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando  a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para comprar abono, semillas entre otros.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en: Cirila belongs to the "SOLIDARIDAD TAMBO REAL" communal bank. She continues with her work raising cattle, work she has been  doing for years. Things are going well for her thanks to the dedication she brings to her work each day. Cirila grows potatoes and corn. She wants to continue to work in this manner so she can continue to support her family. She is requesting a loan to buy manure and seeds amongst others. Cirila is happy with her loan and promises to pay the installments of her loan.

loans.use: top buy manure, seeds, etc.

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en:
Chorn is a 59-year-old mother of eight children living in a rural village of the Kampong Svay district, Cambodia. To make a living, she and her husband have been farming rice and selling grocery items, and her husband supplements the family’s income by working as a paid worker. The current business earns her about US$14 per day. 

This is the first micro-loan for Chorn with VisionFund. Now she is applying for a loan to pay her daughter's tuition fees to study accounting. She hopes to keep her children in school until graduation.

loans.use: to pay her daughter's tuition fees to study accounting

location.town: Kampong Thom Province, Kampong Svay District

loans.name: Pey

texts.en:
Originally from a village of the Kampong Svay district, where rice farming is a common way to make a living, Pey is a 43-year-old mother of four children. Rice farming is the main source of the family’s income, which she and her husband have been in for 23 years. Her husband supplements the income by working for others for a fee. 

This is Pey's microloan with Kiva’s partner. Now she is seeking a loan to pay her son’s tuition fee. She hopes her son will get a good job after graduation.

loans.use: to pay her son’s tuition fee

location.town: Kampong Thom Province, Kampong Svay District

loans.name: Rustica

texts.en:
Rustica is a businesswoman from Lopez Jaena. She has a sari-sari (variety) store that helps support the needs of her family. Rustica owes her capital from PMPC and would always access it for her funding needs. 

Recently, she applied for a loan to restock her store with basic commodities. She hopes to sustain her business and to support the education of her children to earn their diplomas.

loans.use: to restock her store with basic commodities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her child’s education

loans.name: Pov's Group

texts.en:
Living in a rural area located in Battambang province’s Bovel district, Pov, 46, has five children in total, two of whom are dependents and still in school. Pov and her husband are farmers who have been farming rice and corn for 12 years to make a living. 

Pov has been with VisionFund for five loan cycles and completely paid back the loans, which have helped her improve her livelihood from cycle to cycle. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. As the leader, Pov is going to use her portion to pay for school materials for supporting her children’s education. She hopes to better support her children with enough school supplies.

loans.use: to pay for school materials for supporting her children’s education

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a dedicated small holder farmer from Kaduna. As a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ibrahim can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Ibrahim is ambitious and is aiming to reap 30 bags on his 0.50ha farm this season. When asked, Ibrahim said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, in 5 years, I want to ensure that I can make more money for myself and family.” With this loan, Ibrahim is on his way to achieving this dream

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Magaji

texts.en: Magaji remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Magaji, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Magaji is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, expressed Magaji.  With this loan, Magaji is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Yusuf, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yusuf is ambitious and is aiming to reap 50 bags per hectare this season.  Yusuf “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community and build a better home for my children Patrick, Florence and Angelina.” expressed Yusuf. With this loan, Yusuf is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Hamza

texts.en: Hamza is a Babban Gona farmer from Dogonfako. Hamza is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Hamza to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hamza can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Hamza is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Hamza is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Hamza will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es:
La socia continua dedicándose a la ganaderia,la socia es una persona responsable y empeñosa, la socia continua criando a sus animales para continúa vendiéndolos en las distintas ferias que se realizan por la zona, la socia desea poder seguir trabajado para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de una vaca.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en: Sabina continues to raise livestock. She is a responsible and determined person. She continues raising her animals and selling them at the different markets that happen in her area. She wants to keep working in this manner in order to be able to support her family. She is requesting a loan to buy a cow. Sabina is happy with the loan and promises to comply with the payment of her installments.

loans.use: to buy a cow.

loans.name: Sa'adu

texts.en: Sa'adu is a Babban Gona farmer from Dogonfako. Sa'adu is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Sa'adu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Sa'adu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Sa'adu is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Sa'adu is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home.  Ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community." With this loan, Sa'adu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Willy

texts.en:
Willy is 48 years old. He is married and has three children, ages 18, 14, and 2. Two of his children are currently attending school.

Willy operates his own Zoona mobile money transfer business, and he is also an agro-dealer in his hometown of Kalomo, located in the Southern province of Zambia.

Willy works very hard to support his family and parents. He has been operating his Zoona business for six months now. Willy says his community benefits from the business because it is a cheap, user-friendly way for everyone to safely move money around the country using just a simple mobile phone. 

He enjoys running the business because it gives him the chance to interact with people in his community on a daily basis. Willy is requesting a Kiva loan to increase his working capital; this is the money he uses to serve customers' money-transfer needs on a daily basis. Increasing his working capital will enable Willy to serve more customers and earn additional income. Willy emphasizes how having liquidity is key to making money in the business so you never have to turn any potential customers away.

With this loan Willy is excited to see how the additional capital will allow him to grow his business, earn more profit, and provide better for his family’s needs.

loans.use: to increase his working capital. This is the money he uses to serve customers' money-transfer needs on a daily basis

loans.name: Shekilango Group

texts.en:
Emmy is a member of Shekilango group, who joined together to find financial support. This is a new group via Tujijenge Tanzania, and Emmy is the featured person who carries the profile. 

Emmy is in her mid-thirties and has two school-age kids. She is not married, and, for two years, she has been supporting her family by running a shop selling soft drinks. She works from 8 am to 9 pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly return. 

This is her first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she will use to buy soft drinks for her business. She dreams of building a house for her family. Emmy will share this loan with her loan group, Shekilango, which consists of three members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Walter

texts.es:
El socio sigue dedicándose a la ganaderia,el socio es una persona responsable y empeñoso, el socio continua criando a sus animales para luego venderlos  a sus clientes que le solicitan, el socio se siente agradecido por el crédito otorgad y se compromete  a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas, él socio desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
El socio solicita el crédito para arreglar su establo.
texts.en: Walter continues working with livestock. He is a responsible and determined person. He is still raising his animals and selling them to his clients who demand them. Walter feels grateful for the loan and promises to pay his installments as established. He wants to keep working in this manner so he can support his family. He is requesting the loan to fix his cow shed.

loans.use: to fix his cow shed.

loans.name: Iliya Jaji

texts.en: Iliya Jaji remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Iliya Jaji, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Iliya Jaji is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community and provide more food and clothing for my children Sule,Habila and Bilya.” expressed Iliya Jaji. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for his daughter's school expenses.

loans.name: Gaydh Group

texts.en: Gaydh Group, which contains of eight female and two male members, has small businesses in Hargeisa City. The group, which supports a total of around 100 dependents, has been in business for several years. Fosiya Gaydh (who has her hand raised in the group photo) is the group leader. She is a breadwinner and the mother of 11 children. She has a small retail shop in Mawel mini-market at Hargeisa Somaliland. The main products sold by Fosiya's shop include basic kitchen utensils and women’s clothes. A requested loan of $600 could bring her business to the upper ladder and improve the standard of living of her family members. Although each and every individual will take his/her loans separately, they are a group of 10 members.

loans.use: to expand her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her daughter's education.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine and embroidery machine.

loans.name: Raquel

texts.es:
Raquel es una mujer de 41 años de edad casada, madre de tres hijos y su negocio es la venta de pollo a la broaster (pollo frito).
Ella es una mujer fuerte, luchadora y emprendedora, lleva en este negocio un año, en la zona de ‘plan 3000’ distante  a treinta minutos de la ciudad de la Santa Cruz. Este lugar comenzó como un barrio marginal de esa ciudad, poco a poco fue creciendo hasta convertirse en una zona comercial y muy poblada.
Raquel es una persona tranquila de buen humor y muy buena atención al cliente. Su negocio lo realiza en su domicilio, en un espacio que habilitó como restaurante al aire libre porque en la zona hace bastante calor. Su sueño es la ampliación de su negocio y que sea reconocido por su buena cocina, ella trabaja al lado de sus tres hijos, quienes después de la escuela retornan a su hogar y se hacen cargo de la cocina y la limpieza.
Es por esos motivos que Raquel solicita un préstamo para la ampliación de su negocio y poder darles un futuro mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Raquel is a 41 year old woman, who is married and is mother to three children. Her business is selling roasted chickens. She is a strong woman, a fighter and entrepreneur. She has had this business for a year in an area called 'Plan 3000’ 30 minutes away from the city of Santa Cruz. This neighborhood started as a marginal neighborhood of the city and little by little has expanded into a commercial and highly populated zone.

Raquel is a calm person with good humor who provides very good service to her customers. She does her business from her house in a space that is made into a restaurant. It is outside as the area is fairly hot. Her dream is to expand her business and be recognized as a good cook. She works along with her three children, who after school return home and take charge of the kitchen and cleaning. For these reasons Raquel is requesting a loan to expand her business and be able to provide her children with a better future.

loans.use: to expand her business and provide a better future for her children.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a sewing machine and fabric.

loans.name: Hambal Group

texts.en: Ubah Omer is a 46-year-old woman. She has nine children, seven males and two females. She is the one raising her hand in the group photo. Ubah is the leader of a group named Hambal, which consists of 10 members. Hambal group consists of six women and four men. All of the group members have an existing small or medium-sized business in Hargeisa City. Ubah has a medium-sized retail cafeteria in Somaliland parliamentary compound in the capital of Hargeisa. The main products Ubah sells are coffee, black tea, and soft foods. She requested a loan amount of $700 from Kaaba MFI to expand her cafeteria. Hambal members are a group, but each and every person has his/her loan, as all of them have existing businesses.

loans.use: to expand her cafeteria

loans.name: Salisu Inyas

texts.en: Salisu Inyas is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Salisu Inyas joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children. Salisu Inyas is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Salisu Inyas will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Salisu Inyas can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Salisu Inyas is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Carlos Eduardo

texts.es:
El señor Carlos Eduardo de 35  años de edad es casado viven con sus hijos que dependen de él y su esposa,  vive en una comunidad de San Lorenzo en la zona sur de Honduras.

Don Carlos Eduardo se dedica desde 3 y medio al negocio de venta de productos plásticos como pailas, soperas, platos, pazcones, sombrillas, etc. y también vende ropa, sale todos los días en su bici taxi a realizar su trabajo que es la venta de plástico visita pulperías.

Don Carlos está solicitando el préstamo para la compra de pailas, soperas, platos, pazcones, sombrillas, etc. y así surtir mas su negocio con el apoyo de este crédito el pretende mejorar su negocio y por ende su calidad de vida, sueño es tener el mejor negocio en la zona de forma ambulante.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio del 2014.
texts.en:
Carlos Eduardo is 35 years old, married and lives with his children and wife who are dependent on him. He lives in the community of San Lorenzo in the southern part of Honduras.

Carlos Eduardo has worked for the past three and a half years selling plastic goods like containers, cutlery, plates, pans, umbrellas etc. He also sells clothing. He goes out every day on his bicycle taxi to do his work which is selling the plastic items to small stores.

Don Carlos is requesting a loan to buy containers, cutlery, plates, pans, umbrellas etc. to stock his business. He hopes to improve his business with the help of this loan and in the end improve his quality of living. His dream is to have the best mobile business in the area.
San Lorenzo, Honduras - July 2014.

loans.use: to buy containers, cutlery, plates, pans, umbrellas etc. for his business.

loans.name: Mujeres Independientes Group

texts.es:
16 son las mujeres que integran este grupo, pero por este ciclo solo 15 solicitan este préstamo, ellas son mujeres jefas de familia, que a través de la encuesta de eliminación de la pobreza, podrán conocer la situación de cada una y conforme a ello poder trabajar.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra.  Maria, quien es la presidenta del grupo, ella siempre trata de poder motivar a sus amigas a trabajar y poder salir adelante, ella se dedica a vender cosméticos variados, y comenta que tiene una buena clientela que siempre compra de ella sus productos.
Pide este préstamo para poder comprar cosméticos de mayor variedad, de manera a captar el interés de sus clientas, pues por medio de su trabajo mantiene a su familia.
texts.en:
There are 16 women in this group, but in this cycle only 15 are requesting the loan.  The women are heads of family who, through the poverty-elimination survey, will be able to find out each one's situation and work based on the results.

One of the members is María, the president of the group.  She always tries to motivate her friends to work and get ahead.  She earns a living selling a variety of cosmetics.  She said she has good customers who always buy products from her.

She's requesting this loan to be able to buy a wider variety of cosmetics so she can attract the interest of her customers, because she supports her family with the job.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics

loans.name: Henry Erick

texts.es:
El señor Henry Erick de 35 años de edad es casado tiene dos  hijos  que dependen de él, vive en una comunidad de San Lorenzo, al sur de Honduras, tiene casa propia  y se dedica desde hace 03  años  al negocio de venta  abarrotería en general como ser: granos básicos, frescos, productos lácteos, churros, embutidos, manteca, aceite, jugos, cosméticos, etc. 
Don Henry Erick es un hombre trabajador con deseo de salir adelante, el desea aperturar  un nuevo negocio.
Esta solicitando el préstamo para la  compra de mas mercadería como azúcar, frijoles, arroz, café, agua, manteca, pan, galletas, refrescos, etc. para su pulpería, ya que por estar en una buena zona de comercio su venta es muy buena y  además el vende otros productos que también le generan una buena utilidad  con el apoyo del crédito el pretende mejorar sus ingresos.
Uno de sus sueños es abrir un nuevo negocio de venta de repuestos de moto.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio del 2014.
texts.en:
Henry Erick, 35, is married with two dependent children. He lives in the community of San Lorenzo in southern Honduras. He has his own house and entered the grocery business 3 years ago. He sells general goods like basic staple products, fresh dairy products, churros, sausages, butter, cooking oil, juice, cosmetics, and more.

Henry Erick is a hardworking man with a desire to succeed. He wants to open a new business one day. 

He is requesting a loan to buy more goods such as sugar, beans, rice, coffee, bottled water, butter, cookies, soft drinks, and more for his store. It is located in a good area of trade and his sales are very good. The new products sold will also generate a good income to support his family as he aims to improve their income.

One of his dreams is to open a new business selling motorcycle parts.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - July 2014

loans.use: to stock his grocery store with sugar, beans, rice, coffee, and other products

loans.name: Maria Emilia

texts.es:
La señora María Emilia  de 66 años de edad es soltera, no tiene  hijos  que dependen de ella,  vive en una comunidad de San Lorenzo, al sur de Honduras, tiene casa propia  y se dedica desde hace 14  años  al negocio de venta  ropa.
Doña María Emilia  sus ventas las realiza  de forma ambulante también vende en las afueras del mercado nuevo, es una persona trabajadora con deseos de salir adelante ahora desea vender frutas y plásticos.
Doña María Emilia  está solicitando el préstamo para la  compra de ropa blúmeres, braseares, faldas, vestidos, camisas y frutas de la temporada porque quiere empezar a vender frutas, desea invertir en mercadería porque se acerca la época de la feria.
Doña María Emilia  espera que esta inversión le permita mejorar sus ingresos y por ende su calidad de vida, uno de sus sueños es mejorar su casa.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio del 2014.
texts.en:
Maria Emilia is 66 years old. She's single and no longer has dependent children. She lives in the community of San Lorenzo in southern Honduras. She has her own house and has been in business selling clothes for 14 years.

Maria Emilia performs her sales as an ambulant vendor in the outskirts of the new market. She is a hardworking person with a desire to succeed. She also wants to sell fruits and plastic products as well.

Maria Emilia is requesting a loan to purchase clothing such as undergarments, bras, skirts, dresses, shirts, and fruits that are in season because she wants to begin selling fruits. She wants to invest in these goods because the season for outdoor markets is approaching.

Maria Emilia expects that this investment will allow her to improve her income and quality of life. One of her dreams it to improve her house.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - July 2014

loans.use: to purchase clothing and seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Cristina works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store. Cristina is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy additional fishing net for her fishing business.

Cristina has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing net.

loans.name: Lado

texts.en: Lado remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Lado like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Lado,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  Lado expressed that “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, Lado is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 40 years old and married with one child who is in school. Josephine works very hard to provide for them.

Josephine runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. 

Josephine has been in this business for 10 years.

She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine works hard to support her family. Josephine is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Josephine requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stocks to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

Josephine has been in this business for 2 years now.

In the future, Josephine would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Luz works hard to support her family.

She has a buy and sell honey business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store. Luz is borrowing PHP 9,500 through NWTF to purchase additional bottles of honey to sell for her buy and sell honey business.

Luz has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional bottles of honey to sell.

loans.name: Fatmata S

texts.en: This is 26-year-old Fatmata S.  She is married and has 1 child, who is aged 4 years and goes to school. She has 1 additional dependent, who lives with her to be fostered. In 2012, Fatmata S established her provision - mayonnaise, sugar, milk, cooking oil, cream, Maggi, etc. - business. She was introduced to her business by her foster parents. Knowing her background, her husband gave her some amount of money to start a clothing business which she changed to a grocery because of low sales. Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about Le 950,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. Fatmata S. requires a loan in order to purchase cartons of mayonnaise, milk, baby food, assorted maggi cubes and rubbers of cooking oil. In the future, Fatmata S plans to develop her business and improve the business. The loan will improve the business. Lack of some items customers want is her challenge. She is a hardworking and friendly woman. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, milk, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Gibril Akim

texts.en: This is 41-year-old Gibril. He is married and has 1 child aged 14 who goes to school. Gibril owns a business. Working 7 days a week and 9 hours a day, he earns about Le 2,300,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000. Gibril requires a loan in order to buy crates of soft drinks, phone accessories, and batteries. Gibril was able to buy a piece of land and a vehicle. He is now planning to develop the piece of land. The loan will help to improve the business. Changes in prices and high transportation costs are his main challenges. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy additional phones, batteries, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy additional bundles of gin, gallons of fruit wine and crates of soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cotton napkins, towels and baby panties for her clothing business.

loans.name: Markus Goma

texts.en: Markus  Goma remembers the extreme poverty that his family faced  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Markus  Goma, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Markus  Goma  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 15 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Markus. With this loan, Markus  Goma is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine and fabric.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase mobiles and mobile accessories.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
Carlos es un hombre de 40 años de edad soltero, sin hijos y su negocio es la panadería.
Él es una persona constante, madrugador y muy puntual en su trabajo; que lo lleva realizando casi diez años en la zona de Pampahasi de la ciudad de La Paz. Sus inicios fueron como ayudante de panadería, más tarde con el apoyo de su familia se independizó y poco a poco fue comprando sus herramientas de trabajo como; horno industrial, garrafas a gas natural y otros utensilios de panadería.
Carlos es de tez morena, cabello corto, estatura mediana y siempre viste guardapolvo o delantal; su panadería es bastante pequeña sólo caben los instrumentos de trabajo y una persona para ayudar. Su rutina comienza muy temprano por la madrugada con el encendido del horno y la preparación de la masa, todo tiene que estar horneado a las seis y treinta de la mañana, hora en que llegan sus clientes (dueños de tienda de barrio) y se llevan los panes apilados en canastas, con cantidades de trescientos panes aproximadamente. Su sueño es tener una casa propia y una panadería más grande; por eso es que lucha cada día.
Es por esos motivos que Carlos solicita un préstamo para la compra de harina por mayor y poco a poco dar cumplimiento a sus sueños.
texts.en:
Carlos is a 40-year-old man, single, no children and his business is a bakery.
He is a perseverant, early-riser and punctual person in his work; he has worked on this for 10 years in the Pampahasi area of the city of La Paz. His beginnings were as a bakery helper and later on with the support of his family he became independent and slowly bought his work tools such as an industrial oven, natural gas tanks and other baking tools.

Carlos is dark-skinned, short hair, average height and always wears an apron; his bakery is quite small and there’s only room for his tools and 1 more person to help out.  His routine starts very early in the morning  by turning on the oven, preparing the dough and everything has to be baked by 6:30, time when his customers (the owners of the convenience store of the neighborhood) arrive and pick up the bread piled up in baskets, with amounts of 300 pieces approximately.  His dream is to have a house he owns and a bigger bakery; this is why he fights each day.
This is the reason why Carlos requests a loan to buy flour at wholesale and start achieving his dreams little by little.

loans.use: to buy flour at wholesale to achieve his dreams little by little.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 39 years old and married with five children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Nancy is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase additional feed and vitamins.

Nancy has been raising pigs for five years and earns additional income from fishing.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos is a 25-year-old farmer from Kargo.  As a Babban Gona member, Amos is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Amos can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Amos is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least  40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Amos is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Lorence,  and  Mary. Amos’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Mika

texts.en: Mika is a Babban Gona farmer from Kargo. Mika is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is this ambition that led Mika to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Mika can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Mika is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Mika is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Mika will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Malia

texts.en: Malia is a 22-year-old single woman with no children. She runs a small bakery in her community to earn a living. She has one year of experience with this business. Malia needs a loan to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, cooking oil, baking trays, icing sugar, butter and a large stove. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Malia has been a member of SPBD since 2014.

loans.use: to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, cooking oil, baking trays, icing sugar, butter and a large stove

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en: Akenese is a 52-year-old married mother of six children. She runs a small bakery in her community to earn a living. She has four years of experience with this business. Akenese needs a loan to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, cooking oil, baking trays, icing sugar, butter and a large stove. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Akenese has been a member of SPBD since 2010.

loans.use: to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, cooking oil, baking trays, icing sugar, butter and a large stove

loans.name: Pelenatete

texts.en: Pelenatete is a 59-year-old married woman with six children. She runs a small barbeque hut in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Pelenatete needs a loan to buy a new barbecue set, mutton flaps, lamb chops, onions, soy sauce, tomato sauce and sausages. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses and help expand her business. Pelenatete has been a member of SPBD since 2012.

loans.use: to buy a new barbecue set, mutton flaps, lamb chops, onions, soy sauce, tomato sauce and sausages

loans.name: Makerita

texts.en: Makertia is 44 years old and married with four children. She makes and sells elei printed material to earn a living and has been doing this for two years. Makerita has requested a loan to buy material, fabric paint, stencils, brushes, rollers, wooden carved designs and a new cutter. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. She joined SPBD in 2012 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy material, fabric paint, stencils, brushes, rollers, wooden carved designs and a new cutter

loans.name: Suzan Faith

texts.en:
Suzan Faith is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kaliro in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past 2 years, Suzan Faith has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells fast foods. 

To help expand her business, Suzan Faith has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cooking oil and charcoal that will be used in the business, and it will help Suzan Faith to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young sister. Suzan Faith hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another business selling cooked food. 

Suzan Faith is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more cooking oil and charcoal that will be used in her business

loans.name: Tauala

texts.en:
Tauala is a 46-year-old married woman with 5 children.  She operates a small shop in her village.  She joined the SPBD program in 2013 to gain access to financial assistance and has managed to maintain the operation of her shop for a year now. 

She is planning to use this money to purchase a new freezer, flour, sugar, rice, cooking oil, yeast, onions, snacks, soft drinks, chicken leg quarters, sausages, and mutton flaps to restock her shop.  Tauala has managed to make some improvements in the livelihood of her family from the profits she was able to earn from her business.

loans.use: to purchase a new freezer, flour, sugar, rice, cooking oil, yeast, onions, snacks, soft drinks, chicken leg quarters, sausages, and mutton flaps.

loans.name: Raava

texts.en:
Raava is a 47-year-old married woman with 7 children.  She has just joined the SPBD program to gain access to financial assistance so she can help meet her family's financial obligations.  Therefore, she plans to run a small plantation business where she has already started selling some produce to the members of her community, as well as the general public in town.  

With this loan, she plans to purchase a mist blower, bush knives, chemicals, blade sharpner, spades, shovels, taro roots, and ta'amu roots for her plantation.  Raava hopes to save a lot of her profit so she can make improvements to the livelihood of her family.

loans.use: to purchase a mist blower, bush knives, chemicals, blade sharpner, spades, shovels, taro roots, and ta'amu roots.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a hardworking entrepreneur who has operated a cultured seaweed business in the Philippines for 2 years.  She is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase seaweed seedlings and other materials for her business.  Maria also earns additional income from fishing.

Maria has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF.  She dreams of saving enough money to afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase seaweed seedlings and other materials for her business.

loans.name: Foketi

texts.en: Foketi is a 35-year-old single mother of eight children. She runs a small bakery in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Foketi needs a loan to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, cooking oil, baking trays, icing sugar, butter and a large stove. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Foketi has been a member of SPBD since 2012.

loans.use: to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, cooking oil, baking trays, icing sugar, butter and a large stove

loans.name: Guillermo Samuel

texts.es: Guillermo de 71 años de edad se dedica a la compra y venta de hierro, cobre, aluminio, bronce, etc. su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia, con lo que obtiene de su trabajo logra solventar algunas necesidades que se le presentan en el hogar, Guillermo está solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas chatarra por mayor para poder continuar con su trabajo y asi tener junto con su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Guillermo is 71 years old and makes a living buying and selling iron, copper, aluminium, bronze etc. His business is located in his place of residence and, with what he receives from his work, he manages to meet some of the needs that arise in his household. 

Guillermo is asking for a loan in order to buy more scrap metal at wholesale so that he can continue with his work and in this way, together with his family, have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy scrap metal, such as iron, copper, aluminium, bronze, etc. at wholesale.

loans.name: Anasitasia

texts.en: Anasitasia is a 32-year-old single mother of three children. She runs a small barbeque hut in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Anasitasia needs a loan to buy mutton flaps, lamb chops, sausages, soy sauce, tomato sauce, onions and paper plates. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Anasitasia has been a member of SPBD since 2012.

loans.use: to buy mutton flaps, lamb chops, sausages, soy sauce, tomato sauce, onions and paper plates

loans.name: Pauasi

texts.en: Pauasi is 52 years old and single with five children. She makes and sells elei printed material to earn a living and has been doing this for two years. Pauasi has requested a loan to buy material, fabric paint, stencils, brushes, rollers, wooden carved designs and a new cutter. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. She joined SPBD in 2012 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy material, fabric paint, stencils, brushes, rollers, wooden carved designs and a new cutter

loans.name: Masela

texts.en:
Masela is a 53-year-old married woman with 7 children.  She runs a small vegetable garden business where she sells vegetables to the members of her community and to the traveling public.  She joined the SPBD program in 2013 to gain access to financial assistance. 

Masela plans to use this money to purchase a mist blower, chemicals, fertilizers, rakes, and gardening tools to further improve her vegetable business.  She hopes to save most of her profits to expand her vegetable garden, and provide essential every day needs for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a mist blower, chemicals, fertilizers, rakes, and gardening tools.

loans.name: Upuia

texts.en:
Upuia is a 36-year-old woman with 4 children.  She runs a small plantation business selling to the members of her community and to the traveling public.

She plans to use this loan to purchase chemicals, fertilizers, digging tools, and other equipment for the plantation.  She joined SPBD to gain access to financial assistance and has been a member for 2 years now.  Though there are times when she finds it hard to make a profit, she tries to save as much as possible and control her spending. 

Upuia hopes to expand her plantation business in the future so that it will be able to meet her weekly financial obligations.

loans.use: to purchase chemicals, fertilizers, digging tools, and other equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay college tuition fees.

loans.name: Aminata Niamo's Group

texts.fr:
Le banc villageois a été mise en place le 14 Décembre 2010 et pour le nom du village qui l’abrite. Il est composé de femmes dont l’entente et l’organisation sont frappantes. C’est un groupe où l’on note une nette progression depuis leur entrée dans le programme il y’a de cela huit cycle soit quatre ans. Elles mènent diverses activités, principalement le petit commerce, la transformation et l’agriculture sous pluie.

Madame Aminata (debout à l’extrême gauche avec une main levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est mariée, âgée de 61 ans et mère de 04 enfants dont 03 filles et un garçon. Elle est vendeuse de beignets au village, elle vend aussi de l’huile palme qu’elle achète dans un pays frontalier par fût et mène parfois des activités de transformation de savon. Elle jouit d’une bonne expérience dans toutes ses activités pour les avoir pratiqués pendant plus de quinze ans.

Avec son nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter pour la transformation de savon un fût d’huile et 02 sacs de sel. Pour le beignet 20 kg de farine du 5 kg de l’huile 20 litres et divers ingrédients.

Avec les bénéfices, elle prévoit de participer significativement à la gestion de la dépense quotidienne, à soutenir ses enfants dans leur scolarité d’une part et d’autre part à renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
The banc villageois was set up on 14 December 2010 and is for the name of the village that it was started in. It is made up of women who exhibit an excellent understanding and organization [of the program]. This group is one who has shown a clear progression from the entry into the program. They have gone through eight cycles in four years. The women work mostly in small-scale commerce, production, and rain-fed agriculture.

Aminata (who is standing on the far left in the photo with her hand raised) is the featured borrower of this group. She is married, 61 years old, and a mother of four children, of whom three are girls and one is a boy.

Aminata works in the village selling beignets, and she sells palm oil that she buys in a neighboring country. She also sometimes makes soap. She has been successful with this work, which she has done for more than 15 years.

With this new loan, she plans to buy a drum of oil and two sacs of salt to make soap. She will also buy 20 kilograms of flour and five 20-liter drums of oil to make beignets, plus some other ingredients.

With her earnings, Aminata plans take care of many of her family's everyday expenses, support her children's schooling, and increase her savings.

loans.use: to buy oil, salt, flour, and other ingredients

loans.name: Shehu

texts.en: Shehu is a 28-year-old farmer from Ung/Ma'aji.  As a Babban Gona member, Shehu , is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Shehu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Shehu is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Shehu said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children; Poulina, Penihas,  and  Isuwa, and in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Elcira De Jesus

texts.es:
Elcira una mujer de 48 años de edad que debido a su embarazo tuvo que dejar el negocio de las confecciones para dedicarse de lleno a la crianza de su hija.

Una vez su pareja la dejo sola con su hija le toco buscar alternativas para generar ingresos y lo único que encontró es reactivar su empresa de confección a terceros con lo que esperar generar recursos para seguir adelante con su hija. 

Solicita un crédito para reactivar su empresa de confección a terceros con lo que comprara hilos, nailon, realizara mantenimiento a sus máquinas.

Es importante apoyar a esta empresaria pues le brindaran la oportunidad de que pueda continuar aún con la ausencia de su pareja pues tiene una hija que mantener a quien darle estudio y darle una buena vida.
texts.en:
Elcira is a 48 year old woman. Due to her pregnancy, she had to leave the apparel business and devote herself to raising her daughter.

Once her partner left her and her daughter alone, she had to seek alternatives to generate income. The only opportunity she found was to reactivate her clothing manufacturing business selling her products to third parties. She expects to generate resources to continue moving forward with her daughter.

She applied for a loan to revive her clothing business. She will buy thread, nylon, and repair her machines.

It is important to support this business because it provides the opportunity to be able to move forward even in the absence of her partner because she has a daughter to support, educate, and provide a good life for.

loans.use: to reactivate her sewing business as a single mother

loans.name: Ane

texts.en: Ane is a 62-year-old widow with five children. She runs a large cattle farm to earn a living. To earn extra income, she also runs a bakery. Ane needs a loan to buy a 10 young calves, barbed wire and safety gear for the workers and for her bakery a large outdoor oven. She will use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses and help with the expansion of her business. Ane joined SPBD in 2011 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy a 10 young calves, barbed wire and safety gear for the workers and for her bakery, a large outdoor oven

loans.name: Vaai

texts.en: Vaai is a 48-year-old married mother of seven children. She runs a small tailoring business in her community. She has seven years of experience with this business. Vaai has requested a loan to buy two new industrial sewing machines, 100 rolls of thread, 10 rolls of material, a measuring tape, a new pair of scissors and a large table. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses and help with the expansion of her business. She joined SPBD in 2007 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy two new industrial sewing machines, 100 rolls of thread, 10 rolls of material, a measuring tape, a new pair of scissors and a large table

loans.name: Rahama

texts.en: Rahama remembers being very depressed during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Rahama, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Rahama  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Rahama   With this loan, Rahama is well on her way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
El grupo Mujeres Trabajadoras  está en su segundo ciclo  del programa de comité de mujeres, donde ellas estan haciendo la encuesta de eliminacion de pobreza, para poder mejorar las condiciones de vida de cada una por medio del trabajo en conjunto.
Una de ellas es la señora Maria, quien se dedica al comercio, ella tiene una despensa bien surtida en la que trabaja todos los días desde muy tempranas horas, Maria esta luchando por poder crecer en su negocio y poder tener mejores ingresos para su familia.
Ella pide este prestamo para poder comprar insumos para su despensa, como ser verduras, frutas, carne, embutidos, y demás de productos a poder seguir con sus ventas como lo viene haciendo.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Trabajadoras or Working Women’s group is in the second cycle of the women’s committee program, in which they are completing the ‘poverty elimination’ questionnaire in order to improve living conditions for each participant by working together. 

One of the members is Maria, who runs a retail business. She has a well-stocked small grocery store where she works from the early hours of the morning every day. Maria is working hard to augment her business and generate better income for her family.

She is requesting this loan to buy supplies for her store, such as vegetables, fruit, meat, sausages, and other products so she can continue her sales as she has in the past.

loans.use: to buy supplies such as vegetables, fruit, meat, sausages, and other products to sell.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena is a 54-year-old widow with two children. She owns and operates a small store, selling a variety of items. She has been doing this for four years. Elena needs a loan to buy a new display refrigerator, a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, sack of onions, potatoes, vegetables and a large hanging scale. She hopes to use her profits to pay for the renovation of her house and help pay for her children's education. She became a member of SPBD in 2010 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy a new display refrigerator, a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, sack of onions, potatoes, vegetables and a large hanging scale

loans.name: Sefulu

texts.en: Sefulu is a 48-year-old married woman with five children. She operates a taxi business and owns a cattle farm. She joined SPBD in 2013 in order to gain access to financial assistance and she has found that the income she gets from her taxi business is doing well. She plans to expand her cattle farm thus reason for the usage of this money. She plans to purchase two cows, ropes, and fencing wire for her cattle farm. Sefulu has found that she has managed to improve the livelihood of her family with the profits she has been getting.

loans.use: to purchase two cows, ropes, and fencing wire

loans.name: Fuaselela

texts.en:
Fuaselela, age 52 and widowed, runs a small shop in her village to earn a living. She has been in operation for more than three years and has been a member of the SPBD program for more than seven years. 

Fuaselela has five children. Since Fuaselela joined SPBD, she has managed to improve her livelihood and her family's standard of living, and she has been better able to provide for her family's essential needs.

She plans to use her loan funds to restock her store. She will buy such items as sugar, flour, rice, onions, snacks, chicken pieces, mutton flaps, sausages, soft drinks, coffee, and tea, as well as laundry detergent and soap. She will also purchase a new freezer.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items to offer for sale in her store, as well as to buy a new freezer

loans.name: Virgen De Fatima Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama Virgen de Fatima, tiene 18 integrantes, son mujeres jefas de familia, que se están esforzando por poder salir adelante y ayudar a sus familias, son muy luchadoras y por sobre todo muy emprendedoras.
Araceli es una de las que integran este grupo, ella se dedica a hacer comidas, comenta que tiene muy buena clientela que siempre compra de ella las comidas que hace. Araceli es muy sacrificada y emprendedora que esta luchando por salir adelante.
Pide este préstamo para comprar insumos para poder seguir haciendo las comidas que vende, como ser verduras, condimentos, carne, hortalizas y demás, y con ello poder ir mejorando sus condiciones de vida y las de su familia.
texts.en: The group is called "Virgen de Fatima" and it has 18 members. They are all mothers and heads of families who are working to get ahead and to help their families. They are fighters and moreover very enterprising. Araceli is one of the group and she works making meals. She comments that she has a very good clientele who always buy the meals she makes. Araceli is very demanding and entrepreneurial and strives to get ahead. She is requesting this loan to buy supplies to be able to continue to prepare the meals that she sells, buying vegetables, spices, meat, greens and others so she can improve her living conditions and that of her family.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, spices, meat, greens, etc.

loans.name: Talafua

texts.en: Talafua is a 67-year-old widow with seven children. She has a large plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for eight years. Talafua needs a loan to buy chemicals, 20 bags of fertilizer, two new wheelbarrows, four tillers, a rake, two new gum boots and a mini tractor. She has been a member of SPBD since 2006. Talafua will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, 20 bags of fertilizer, two new wheelbarrows, four tillers, a rake, two new gum boots and a mini tractor

loans.name: Nuufou

texts.en:
Nuufou is 34 years old and married with seven children. She has a large plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for three years. Nuufou needs a loan to buy 10 bags of fertilizer, a mini tractor, five tillers, chemicals, two shovels, two wheelbarrows and 10 machetes. 
She has been a member of SPBD since 2011. Nuufou will use the profits from her sales to pay for her families weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy 10 bags of fertilizer, a mini tractor, five tillers, chemicals, two shovels, two wheelbarrows and 10 machetes

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en: Faafetai is a 42-year-old married woman with 3 children. She runs a small plantation business selling to the members of her community and to the travelling public. Faafetai joined the SPBD program in 2011 to gain access to financial assistance. With this money, Faafetai plans to purchase a mist blower, chemicals, fertilizers, taro roots, digging tools and equipment to improve her plantation business. She has managed to improve her family's livelihood since she started operating her business but hopes to expand it in the future and increase their income.

loans.use: to purchase a mist blower, chemicals, fertilizers, taro roots, digging tools and equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a large printing machine, Samoan t-shirts, printed material, cava bowls, coconut carved earrings, bangles and Samoan-designed caps

loans.name: G.s Cristo Es Amor Group

texts.es:
El señor Manuel de Jesús de 51  años de edad vive con su esposa tiene 02 hijos  que dependen de él, vive en una comunidad de  Nacaome, valle  al sur de Honduras, tiene casa propia  y se dedica desde hace 05  años  a la venta de maíz para hacer tortillas.
Don Manuel de Jesús también vende maicillo para cría de gallinas y cerdos además sale a vender en su bicicleta pescado rojo y blanco, es una persona trabajadora con deseos de salir adelante.
Don Manuel de Jesús necesita el préstamo para la compra de maíz, al igual que sus compañeros de grupo espera que la inversión que realicen a sus negocios les permita obtener las ganancias suficientes para lograr salir adelante con su familia.
Don Manuel sueño es mejorar su negocio y su casa.
Doña Delsy se dedica al negocio de abarrotería en su comunidad
Doña Adela se dedica a la venta de ropa usada, desean surtir  mas sus negocios. 

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio del 2014.
texts.en:
Manuel de Jesús is 51  years old and lives with his wife and two children who are dependent on him. He lives in a community in Nacaome, a valley in the south of Honduras. He has his own house and for the past five years he has been working selling corn to make tortillas. Manuel de Jesús also sells sorghum to raise chickens and pigs. He also goes out on his bicycle to sell red and white fish. He is a very hard-working person with the desire to get ahead. 

Manuel de Jesús needs a loan to buy corn. He like all the members of his group hope that the investment made to his business will allow him to make enough profit for him to get ahead together with his family. Manuel's dream is to improve his business and his house. 

Delsy has a grocery store in her community and Adela works selling used clothing. They want to stock their businesses more.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - July 2014.

loans.use: to buy corn for his business.

loans.name: Iulai

texts.en:
Iulai, age 40, grows and sells bananas and coconuts to earn an income. She harvests her produce from her small plantation and offers it for sale to members of her local community and to the greater public.

She has been a member of SPBD for more than four years. She has managed to improve her family's standard of living since joining the program. 

Iulai plans to use her loan funds to purchase fertilizers, chemicals, shovels, and spades for her banana plantation, as well as to pay laborers' wages. She will also pay school fees for her children's education. 

Iulai hopes to expand her banana plantation in the future. She plans to grow her savings with her increased profits.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, chemicals, shovels, and spades for her banana plantation, as well as to pay laborers' wages and school fees for her children

loans.name: Saratu Dantani

texts.en: Saratu Dantani remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Saratu Dantani, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Saratu Dantani is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  Dantani “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs,”  expressed Saratu. With this loan, Saratu Dantani is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Hernando De Jesús

texts.es:
Hernando es un hombre veterano de 60 años con un feliz matrimonio el cual hace 6 años monto un negocio de comidas rápidas, frituras y comidas en  general típicas de la región.
