loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Fatima works hard to support her family.

She has a buy and sell dry goods business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from direct selling personal collection products. Fatima is borrowing 15,000 (PHP) through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase more stocks of dry goods like blankets, blouses, etc. to sell to her customers for her buy and sell dry goods business.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Fatima has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of dry goods like blankets, blouses, etc. to sell to her customers

loans.name: Cesaria

texts.en:
Cesaria is 55 years old, married and has four children. Two of her children are in school.

Cesaria is in the agricultural business of poultry in the Philippines. Cesaria requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamin for her poultry.

Cesaria has been in the poultry business for five years now, and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Cesaria would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamin for her poultry.

loans.name: Joselyn

texts.en:
Joselyn is a married woman with six children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Joselyn is 40 years old and has four children who are in school.

She has a food stall business in the Philippines. Joselyn requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more snack food to sell in her food stall.

She has been in this business for two years.  In the future, Joselyn would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more snack food to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is 54-year-old, and married with four children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Teresa is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Teresa has been raising pigs for five years and also earns additional income from fish vending.

She is working tirelessly towards achieving her dream which is to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Ronny

texts.en:
Thirty-two-year-old Ronny has continued to grow his business through hard work and the support he has received from Kiva lenders. He now employs six young adults at his outlets, two men and four women.

Ronny is grateful to all Kiva lenders as he has been able to provide for his three children and wife without many difficulties as his business has steadily grown. Through his loans, he has opened two additional outlets. He has also used the loans to vastly improve his business's resources. He purchased three laptops and three internet modems for his employees to operate the business more efficiently. This brings him more customers now as they see his business as being professional and reliable when needing to send and receive money as well as pay bills.

Today, Ronny is requesting his third Kiva loan to purchase an additional laptop. He has realized that using laptops to facilitate transactions makes the business more efficient. By serving customers quicker, Ronny is able to earn more profit from the increased turnover.

Ronny is very excited about this loan. He has fully repaid his first loan and continues to make his repayments on his second loan on time. He is working hard to ensure that he keeps growing his mobile money transfer business so that he stays capable of providing for all his family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase an additional laptop so that he can serve customers faster

loans.name: Benkadi Iii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI III est constitué de10 femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 5 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à SIRAKORO, un des villages de BOUGOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles hivernale. 
Elles sont à leur 3ème prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
Le riz est la spéculation cultivée de AMINE, la 1ère femme debout  dans la photo de la droite vers la gauche.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, la semence, payer les frais de labour et de sarclage pour exploiter 1,5 hectares. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village, au marché, après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice  de 35.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de rembourser son prêt et  d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de leur ménage.
texts.en:
The Benkadi III group consists of ten married women who on average are 32 years old with five children, all living in polygamous families in Sirakoro, one of the villages of Bougouni in the third administrative region of Mali.

They have been working with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution in carrying out their winter farming activities. They are on their third loan with the institution, and past loans were fully reimbursed.

The selected crop is rice featuring Amine, the first woman standing from right to left in the photo. With her ​​loan, she will buy agricultural inputs and seeds, and pay for plowing and weeding to maintain 1.5 hectares (about 3.7 acres).

After the harvest the production will be sold in the village market to a clientele composed of men and women.

She expects to make a profit of 35,000 CFA francs per growing season. This profit will enable her to repay the loan and help her husband with daily household expenses.

loans.use: Buy agricultural inputs and seeds, and pay for plowing and weeding

loans.name: Benkadi Iv Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI IV est constitué de 7 femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 31 ans et 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à SIRAKORO, un des villages de BOUGOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles hivernale. 
Elles sont à leur  3ème prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
L’arachide est la spéculation cultivée de KARIDIA KARIM, la 2ème femme debout dans la photo de la gauche vers la droite.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des semences, payer les frais de labour et de sarclage pour exploiter  1 hectare. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village, au marché, après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice  de 10.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de rembourser son prêt et  d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de leur ménage.
texts.en:
The Benkadi IV group consists of seven married women who on average are 31 years old with four children, all living in polygamous families in Sirakoro, one of the villages of Bougouni in the third administrative region of Mali.

They have been working with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution in carrying out their winter farming activities. They are on their third loan with the institution, and past loans were fully reimbursed.

Groundnuts is the crop selected by Karida Karim, the second woman standing from left to right in the photo. With her ​​loan she will buy seeds, and pay for plowing and weeding to maintain one hectare (about 2.47 acres).

After the harvest the production will be sold in the village market to a clientele composed of men and women.

She expects to make a profit of 10,000 CFA francs per growing season, which will enable her to repay the loan and help her husband with daily household expenses.

loans.use: Buy seeds; pay for plowing and weeding

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila has the good fortune on having a buy-and-sell dried fish business. This has helped her family earn a good income for more than 10 years. Leonila owes her capital needs to PMPC and is still thankful for all the support that the cooperative has given her.

Recently, she applied a loan to buy more kilos of dried fish to resell. She wants to increase her stocks to earn more. Leonila hopes to maintain her membership with PMPC so that she can always run to the cooperative for any financial support.

loans.use: to buy more kilos of dried fish to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy new business chairs and cooking ingredients.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 51 years old and widowed with four children, one of whom is in school. Grace works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

Grace has been in this business for seven years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap and other groceries. 

In the future Grace would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is 31 years of age and recently got married to his long time fiancée. He is grateful for his business that has been steadily growing because of the financial help he has received through Kiva lenders. Henry’s previous loans enabled him to expand his business by opening two new outlets.

Henry enjoys the business because he is able to interact with different people and provide a needed service within his community. Now, Henry employs three tellers to assist him with the day-to-day operations of the business. His plan is to open two additional outlets and hire two more employees to help with running the new locations.

This loan will enable Henry to purchase a banded Zoona mobile money trading booth where he will operate his new location. This new location will give Henry the opportunity to grow his business and earn additional profit.

loans.use: to purchase a banded Zoona mobile money trading booth where he will operate his new location

loans.name: Benkadi V Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI V  est constitué de 8 femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35  ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à SIRAKORO, un des villages de BOUGOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles hivernale. 
Elles sont à leur  3ème prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
Le  riz est la spéculation cultivée de MAÏMOUNA, la  3ème femme debout dans la photo de la gauche vers la droite.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, la semence, payer les frais de labour et de sarclage pour exploiter  1,5 hectares. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village, au marché, après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice  de 20.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de rembourser son prêt et  d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de leur ménage.
texts.en:
The Benkadi V group consists of eight married women who on average are 35 years old with four children, all living in polygamous families in Sirakoro, one of the villages of Bougouni in the third administrative region of Mali.

They have been working with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution in carrying out their winter farming activities. They are on their third loan with the institution, and past loans were fully reimbursed.

Rice is the crop selected by Maïmouna, the third woman standing from left to right in the photo. With her ​​loan she will buy agricultural inputs and seeds, and pay for plowing and weeding to maintain one and a half hectares (about 3.7 acres).

After the harvest the production will be sold in the village market to a clientele composed of men and women.

She expects to make a profit of 20,000 CFA francs per growing season, which will enable her to repay the loan and help her husband with daily household expenses.

loans.use: Buy agricultural inputs and seeds, and pay for plowing and weeding.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en: Delia has mastered her skills in making bread. She has her own unique bread recipe and she is known of her homemade sweet bread. This has kept her business going for more than 5 years now. Recently, Delia requested a loan to buy more kilos of flour, sugar and margarine for bread production. Delia hopes to expand her business by displaying in more store outlets.

loans.use: to buy more kilos of flour, sugar and margarine for bread production.

loans.name: Ma. Lyn

texts.en:
Ma. Lyn is 27 years old, married, with one child who is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Ma. Lyn has a restaurant business in the Philippines. Ma. Lyn requested a 10,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan amount through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) in order to buy ingredients for her restaurant.

Ma. Lyn has been in this business for five years. In the future, Ma. Lyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her restaurant.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 60 years old and married. Helen works very hard to provide for her family.

Helen runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

Helen has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, sugar, coffee, detergent soap, shampoo, noodles, etc. 

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Helen would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Alice Jane is 17 years old and is studying Hotel and Restaurant Management. She is currently in the first year of this 2-year course.

Alice Jane needs PHP 5000 to pay for her tuition fees for the first semester of the school year 2014-2015.

When she graduates, Alice Jane plans to be employed so that she can help her parents.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is 43 years old and married with four children who are all in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Merlita has a fishing business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 20,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

Merlita has been in this business for twenty years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Kasongo

texts.en:
Kasongo is a 33-year-old single mother with three children aged four, three and one. She runs her own Zoona mobile money transfer business in Lusaka, Zambia.

Kasongo has always wanted to operate her own business. When the opportunity came through Zoona she quickly took advantage of it. Access to financial services in Zambia is both scarce and expensive. As most Zambians live in rural areas, distance and transportation factors hinder access to available financial services. Zoona is a company that specializes in low-cost mobile money and other financial transaction services by propagating an open network using small businesses called Zoona agents. Kasongo is a Zoona agent.

Kasongo believes her community benefits from her business in a very positive way because the service she provides is faster compared to other money transfer services and more often has enough cash to pay out receiving customers. Kasongo is requesting for her first Kiva loan to purchase her trading booth outright, allowing her to own a portable storefront and be able to eliminate her current rental payments. 

Kasongo has many dreams for her future, she hopes to take her children to good schools. She also hopes to employ people to help her at her shop as she currently operates the business alone.

loans.use: to purchase her trading booth outright, allowing her to own a portable storefront.

loans.name: Florida

texts.en:
Florida is 56 years old and married with six children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Florida is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to buy feeds, vitamin and vaccines for her pigs.

Florida has been raising pigs for 5 years and also earns additional income from food vending.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds, vitamin and vaccines for her pigs.

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en:
Anahit is 63 years old and lives in Sevan City of Gegharkunik region. She lives with her husband; their children are married and they live separately with their families. Anahit’s husband works as a head of a village condominium and here Anahit works as an inspector. Anahit also runs a farm with her husband, which brings some more income for their family. They also manage to support financially their children’s families. Anahit is very hard-working woman, but lately the weakness and unhealthy, tired feelings make her very upset and she decided to find out the cause of these.
 
Anahit asks for this loan in order to pass a medical examination and find out the problem and maybe she will also have a course of treatment.

loans.use: to pay for a medical examination and maybe also have a course of treatment.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 55 years old and married with seven children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Rebecca has a fishing business in the Philippines. Rebecca requested a PHP 14,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

Rebecca has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Rebecca would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Benkadi Vi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI VI est constitué de 8 femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37ans et 5 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à SIRAKORO, un des villages de BOUGOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles hivernale. 
Elles sont à leur  3ème prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
L’arachide est la spéculation cultivée de ADIARA MADOU, la 1ère femme debout dans la photo de la droite vers la gauche.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des semences, payer les frais de labour et de sarclage pour exploiter  3 hectares. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village, au marché, après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice  de 60.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de rembourser son prêt et  d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de leur ménage.
texts.en:
The Benkadi VI group consists of eight married women who on average are 37 years old with five children, all living in polygamous families in Sirakoro, one of the villages of Bougouni in the third administrative region of Mali.

They have been working with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution in carrying out their winter farming activities. They are on their third loan with the institution, and past loans were fully reimbursed.

Groundnuts is the crop selected by Adiara Madou, the first woman standing from right to left in the picture. With her ​​loan she will buy seeds, and pay for plowing and weeding to maintain three hectares (about 7.4 acres).

After the harvest the production will be sold in the village market to a clientele composed of men and women.

She expects to make a profit of 60,000 CFA francs per growing season, which will enable her to repay the loan and help her husband with daily household expenses.

loans.use: Achat des semences, payer les frais de labour et de sarclage.

loans.name: Tamari

texts.en: Tamari is 44 years old from the small village of Gardabani district. She lives with her husband, two sons and parents-in-law. Her parents-in-law are provided with the retirement pension. Her sons go to the local school. She graduated from pedagogical college and works as teacher at the local public school. Unfortunately a teacher’s salary is not enough to make ends meet for a family. In the region there is a high unemployment rate, but self-employment helps inhabitants to make a living. So, she decided to start a husbandry trading business with the loan but the local credit providers usually demand experience and some stable income from the borrowers. Tamari’s credit requests were rejected several times, as she doesn’t satisfied their requirements. She received the credit in the framework of a joint initiative of Kiva and Credo, the so-called Startup Program that gives rural poor people the chance to start or re-start businesses. With the loan of 3700 GEL, she will purchase calves, raise them and start a husbandry business.

loans.use: to purchase calves and start a husbandry business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
As the married parent of three children, Josephine works hard to support her family. She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling mangos. Josephine is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to purchase ingredients like meat, fish, vegetables, spices, etc. for her food vending business.

Josephine has been sustaining her business activities through her past nine loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients like meat, fish, vegetables, spices, etc. for her food production business

loans.name: Llewelyn

texts.en:
Llewelyn is 49 years old and has four children. Llewelyn is married and has three children who are in school.

Llewelyn is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. Llewelyn requested a 20,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) in order to buy more livestock to raise.

Llewelyn has been raising livestock for twenty years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Llewelyn would like to save enough money to expand his business and continue to send his children to college.

loans.use: to buy more livestock to raise.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 42 years old. He lives with his wife and their seven children ages 14, 13, 10, 8, 5, 3 and 1. Five of his children are currently attending school.

James is a teacher by profession. He ventured into business after retiring from his teaching career. He has two photocopying machines in his shop which he uses to serve customers. James recently added mobile money to his product line in an attempt to provide a needed service and improve his shop's revenue.

He started his Zoona mobile money transfer business this month and James is confident it will improve his shop's profit. James is always looking for reliable revenue streams to help him provide a better life for his growing family.

He is requesting a Kiva loan to help him increase his cash-on-hand at his location so he can service the demands of his customer base. The more income he has in his mobile money business, the more opportunity he has to earn attractive commissions and service his customer base in an efficient manner.

James sees this loan as an integral part of successfully growing his business. He thanks the lenders for providing a small business owner like himself such an opportunity.

loans.use: to increase his cash-on-hand at his location so he can service the demands of his customer base.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita is 48 years old and married to Rogelio, a tricycle driver at their village. Lolita's spouse provides transport services to the people in their village. Lolita is now asking for a loan of 5,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy gasoline and pay for maintenance of the motorcycle transport business. This will help maintain safe travel for all the passengers. It will also help gain good profits to be used for the family's future expenses.

loans.use: to buy gasoline and pay for maintenance of the motorcycle transport business

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 11,000 (PHP) through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase additional groceries to sell in her general store.

Rosalie has been in this business for six years. Rosalie earns additional income from food vending.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Rosalie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is 51 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by having a pig-fattening business in the Philippines. Marites is borrowing 20,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Marites has been in pig fattening for seven years and also earns additional income from farming mangoes and coconut.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Irma

texts.en:
Irma is 30 years old. She is married and lives with her husband, two daughters and parents-in-law in Khashuri district. Her husband works as an artisan; he gets orders and renovates houses to generate income. Irma is unemployed now. 

She decided to start a husbandry business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of 3,800 GEL (Georgia lari) to purchase cows. As the cows are purchased, she will start producing dairy products and will sell at a good price. Irma is very motivated to be involved in her own business and awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase cows and start a husbandry business

loans.name: Manana

texts.en:
Manana is 44 years old and from the small village of Zugdidi district. She lives with her large family: husband, mother-in-law and six children. Her mother-in-law is provided with the retirement pension. The family is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, they have a plot of agricultural land, where they grow maize and nut trees. They sell the harvested products seasonally, but the income is not enough for such a large family. 

Manana decided to start a husbandry business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of 1,050 GEL (Georgia lari). With the received credit, she will purchase a cow and will start producing dairy products. She will sell cheese and milk, as well as use it for the children's food. The Start Up program will be a great support for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and start producing dairy products

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Ruby works hard to support her family.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. Ruby is borrowing PHP 7,500 through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell to customers.

Ruby has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is 46 years old and married with five children.

Emily works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,500 loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries to sell.

Emily has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from tricycle transportation.

Emily aspires to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon is 54 years old and married with six children.

Corazon works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Corazon has borrowed and repaid seven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from farming ornamental plants.

Corazon aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Janine

texts.en:
As a married mother of six children, Janine works hard to support her family.

She has a rice retailing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fish vending. Janine is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF in order to purchase more stocks of rice to sell to customers.

Janine has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is a married woman with seven children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Theresa is 46 years old and has three children who are in school.

Theresa has a fish vending business in the Philippines. Theresa requested a PHP 5,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy more fish to sell in her food stall.

Theresa has been in this business for three years. In the future, Theresa would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Nune

texts.en:
Nune lives in Stepanavan of Lori region. She is not married and lives with her mother, who is a pensioner. Nune has vocational education. Thanks to her attended accounting courses many years ago, Nune now has become a very good specialist. Over many years, till now, she earned a living by working as a chief accountant. Now she works at the school as a chief accountant and she also gives paid private courses of accountancy at her house. She has five students and they attend the courses three times in a week. As Nune says she likes her profession which brings constant income to her small family.

Nune now asks for this loan in an amount of 400,000 AMD (Armenian drams) since she wants to buy a computer which will be of great use for her courses at home, and so she also can work from her house which will be very comfortable for her.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Carmin Group

texts.es: Al grupo solidario Carmin lo integran tres mujeres laboriosas y lo coordina la señora Reyna de 44 años de edad y soltera, es propietaria de una pulpería en su domicilio desde hace diez años y solicita el crédito para la compra de arroz, frijol, aceite, azúcar, leche centrolac, queso, crema, café, pastillas varias, frutas y verduras. Las otras integrantes son la señora Ángela de 62 años de edad, quien se dedica a la comercialización de frutas y verduras en el mercado más populoso de la capital desde hace veinte años y el crédito lo solicita para la compra de nancite, mamón, ayote, chayote, yuca, etc., y la señora Jaqueline de 21 años de edad quien comercializa gaseosas, hielo y helados en su domicilio, hace más de un año. Es el primer ciclo que las socias solicitan crédito en esta institución.
texts.en:
The communal bank Carmin consists of three industrious women and their group coordinator is Reyna.  She is 44 years old, single and the owner of a grocery store that she set up in her home ten years ago.  She is requesting a loan to buy rice, beans, oil, sugar, Centrolac milk, cheese, cream, coffee, pastas, fruits and vegetables.  

The other members are Ángela, 62, who sells fruits and vegetables at the busiest market in the capital city where she has been for 20 years.  She is requesting a loan to buy plums, papaw, squash, pear squash, yucca, etc.  Jaqueline, 21, sells sodas, ice and ice cream out of her home and has been in business for over a year.  The group is in its first loan cycle through the institution.

loans.use: To buy staple goods.

loans.name: Carlos Reni

texts.es:
Carlos, es casado vive con su esposa y un hijo de 18 años; es propietario de un taller mecánico que tiene el nombre de  “Taller Amaya”, siendo adolescente estudio Bachillerato Mecánico Automotriz, luego fundo su negocio, trabaja de siete de la mañana a seis de la tarde. 
Invertirá en la compra de cables, aceite, focos, pastillas para frenos, espejos, etc., con otra parte dará mantenimiento a su equipo de trabajo, de esta manera brindara un mejor servicio y aumentara sus ganancias con las que pagara sus deudas y los gastos de su hogar.
Su sueño es equipar su negocio con todo lo necesario para realizar mejor su trabajo y conseguir que su negocio sea autosuficiente.
texts.en:
Carlos is married and lives with his wife and 18-year-old son.  He owns a mechanic workshop called "Taller Amaya".  When he was young he received auto mechanics training and then established his business.  He works from 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.

He will buy cables, oil, headlights, brake pads, mirrors, etc. with part of the loan and use the rest for maintenance of his work equipment.  This will allow him to provide better service and increase his earnings to pay off debt and cover household expenses.

His dream is to equip his business with all he needs to do a better job and attract enough business to be self-sufficient.

loans.use: To buy cables, oil, headlights, brake pads, mirrors, etc. and maintenance for his work equipment.

loans.name: Nivia Maria

texts.es:
La disciplina y los deseos de superación han llevado a salir adelante a Nivia María, quién aparte de estudiar  su cuarto año de la carrera de Administración de Empresas, se dedica al comercio de los cosméticos. Tiene 22 años, está casada y tiene un hijo. Hace cinco años inició en el negocio con el objetivo de obtener fondos para cubrir los gastos de la universidad, lo que ha ido logrando con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación. Ella pone a prueba la frase querer es poder. Su esposo se ha convertido en su mano derecha, le brinda todo su apoyo, para juntos progresar y ofrecerle a su menor un futuro prospero. 
Nivia solicita el crédito para incrementar la producción de su capital, requiere comprar maquillaje, esmalte de uñas, aretes, collares, pulseras, bolsos, entre otros productos. Ella deposita su confianza en el financiamiento puesto que anhela crecer, vender variedad de productos, de manera que pueda ganar más clientela y así lograr obtener mejores ingresos. Es una mujer soñadora y emprendedora, uno de sus planes futuros es establecer una tienda grande y un buffet de comida. Su meta próxima es culminar su carrera universitaria y seguir luchando por cumplir sus ideales.
texts.en:
Discipline and a desire to get ahead are what have motivated Nivia María.  Apart from attending the university and studying her fourth year of business administration, she sells cosmetics.  She is 22 years old, married and has a son.  She started her business five years ago in an effort to earn funds to cover her university expenses, which she has done with much effort and dedication.  She puts to the test the saying "Where there's a will there's a way."  Her husband has become her right-hand-man and gives her all of his support so they can prosper together and give their son a bright future.

Nivia is requesting a loan to increase her work capital to buy make-up, nail polish, earrings, necklaces, bracelets, handbags and other products.  She puts her trust in the loan because she wants to expand and sell a variety of products.  This is so she can attract more customers and earn more income.  She is a goal-oriented entrepreneur with future plans to open a large shop and buffet diner.  Her short-term goal is to get her degree and continue striving toward her goals.

loans.use: To buy make-up, nail polish, earrings, necklaces, bracelets, handbags and other products.

loans.name: G.s Mana Group

texts.es:
La señora María de 48 años de edad, vive con su esposo y su hija  en su casa propia se dedica desde hace 15 años al negocio de venta de desayunos, almuerzos y Cenas,  vive en la ciudad de Nacaome Valle, al sur de Honduras, es una mujer emprendedora con deseos de salir adelante y lucha día con día para mejorar su calidad de vida. 
Doña María está solicitando el préstamo para la compra de carnes, arroz, frijoles, aceite, papas, lechuga, tomates, cebollas, etc. para seguir elaborando sus comidas para la venta, espera que esta inversión le genere los ingresos necesarios para salir adelante con su familia.
Doña María esta en un grupo y al igual que sus compañeras desean que esta inversión les sea de mucha ayuda a sus negocios.
Doña Delmy Fabiola se dedica desde hace 1 año al negocio de venta de golosinas, vende pupusas, hamburguesas, carne asada, frescos naturales, etc.
Doña Caren Edith, se dedica al negocio de pulpería desde hace 5 años.
Doña Fátima se dedica desde hace 3 años al negocio de venta de ropa de segunda.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio de 2014
texts.en:
María, 48, lives with her husband and daughter in her own home.  She has been in business 15 years selling breakfast, lunch and dinner.  She lives in the city of Nacaome Valle in southern Honduras and is an enterprising woman with a desire to get ahead.  She struggles daily to improve her quality of life.

María is requesting a loan to buy meats, rice, beans, oil, potatoes, lettuche, tomatoes, onions, etc. to continue making the food she sells.  She hopes the investment will generate enough income for her family to prosper.  

María is in a group and, like the other members, hopes the loan will be helpful to her business.

Delmy Fabiola has been in business a year selling sweets, pupusas (stuff tortillas), hamburguers, grilled meat, natural drinks, etc.

Fátima has been selling second-hand clothing for three years.


San Lorenzo, Honduras - July, 2014.

loans.use: To buy meat, rice, beans, oil, potatoes, lettuche, tomatoes, onions, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fabrics, needles, shoulder pads, buttons, threads, thimbles, eyelets, lace and a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Ma. Janelin

texts.en:
Ma. Janelin is 43 years old and married with one child.

Ma. Janelin works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Ma. Janelin has borrowed and repaid seven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 13 years and also earns an income from farming ornamental plants.

Ma. Janelin aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 40-year-old farmer from Magajin Gari.  As a Babban Gona member, Hassan, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hassan can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Hassan is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least  40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Hassan is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Zaharadeen,  and  Rabiu. Hassan’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Tamar

texts.en: Tamar is 40 years old. She lives with her two children in Khelvachauri district. Tamar is unemployed at the moment in spite of having high education. There is a high unemployed rate in the region especially among people up to 40. Tamar decided to open a market as she owns commercial space at a crowded place. She requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of USD 800. With the received credit she will purchase a stock of products and will open a market. She will have stable income and will provide better living conditions for her children.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of products and open a food market.

loans.name: Lahsie Grace

texts.en:
As a married mother of five children, Lahsie Grace works hard to support her family.

She has a business making and selling recycled flower pot in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from vegetable vending and food stall businesses. Lahsie Grace is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF in order to buy more stocks of used tires to make flower pots.

Lahsie Grace has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of used tires to make flower pots.

loans.name: Maria Caridad

texts.en:
Maria Caridad is a 41-year-old married woman with three children, all of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Maria Caridad has a jewelry-making business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 13,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy materials and other supplies for her business. She has been in this business for ten years. 

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy materials and other supplies for her jewelry-making business.

loans.name: Aliyu

texts.en: Aliyu is a 36-year-old farmer from Magajin Gari.  As a Babban Gona member, Aliyu, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Aliyu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Aliyu is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least  40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Aliyu is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Mohammed,  and  Murtala,. Aliyu’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Garba

texts.en: Garba remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Garba, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Garba  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Garba   With this loan, Garba is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios is a 43-year-old married woman with two children, both of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Remedios has a mat-weaving business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 7,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy more stocks of pandan leaves for mat-weaving. She has been in this business for twenty years. 

In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of pandan leaves for mat-weaving.

loans.name: Usuman

texts.en: Usuman is a 30 year old farmer from Yalwan Pegi.  As a Babban Gona member, Usuman is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Usuman can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Usuman,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 per hectare this season. When asked , Usuman said “I plan to use the money I make to Build a better home And in 5 years, I want to Become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, he is well  on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Ruzanna

texts.en:
This nice lady’s name is Ruzanna and she lives in the city of Spitak in the Lori region. She is not married and lives alone. She has a higher education and she has never been unemployed thanks to her education, professionalism, polite and kind character. 

For 20 years she worked as Head of Human Resources at the sewing factory of Spitak. Now she works at the Spitak City Municipality. She has worked here already for 5 years and she is a much respected and beloved person among her colleagues. 

Since she lives alone, she has managed to build some savings, thanks to which she is now very close to realizing her dream of many years, which is to repair her house. She just dreamed of repairing her house for many years and has continuously saved, so now she is able to start the work.
 
Ruzanna is asking for this loan since she also wants to buy some new furniture for her new house, and do some final repair work. She says she is making her house more comfortable, more stylish and brighter - a place where she can really relax and enjoy her free time.

loans.use: to buy some new furniture for her newly repaired house, and also to do some final repair work

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael is a 35 year old farmer from Ung/Nakaura.  As a Babban Gona member, Michael is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Michael can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Michael,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 per hectare this season. When asked, Michael said “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home and in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Isah

texts.en: Isah is a 40 year old farmer from Ung/Nakaura.  As a Babban Gona member, Isah is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Isah can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Isah is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 per hectare this season. When asked, Isah said “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home and in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en: Anthony remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Anthony, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Anthony  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Anthony   With this loan, Anthony is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a stone crushing machine.

loans.name: Rotha

texts.en: Rotha is 23 years old, a farmer and a married woman with a child. She has been a farmer since 2005. Her husband is a motor mechanic and he has been in this job since 2009. They live in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. They can earn approximately $13 per day. Now she would like to request a loan to buy a plot of land and build a house. This loan will help her have enough money to buy a plot of land and build a house. In the future, she is going to build a bigger stall for her husband for repairing motors and help her child to go to university.

loans.use: to buy a plot of land and build a house

loans.name: Bartholomeus Frans

texts.en: Bartholomeus is a young man living in a remote village far from the big city, specifically in the area of Lembata, East Nusa Tenggara. Bartholomeus is a prospective student at the Academy of Maritime Nusantara (AMN). He wants to get into the management and harbor cruise commerce program because he wants to work in a large port. The parents of Bartholomeus only work as agricultural laborers and their income is uncertain. His parents have only enough revenue to finance the family's daily life. Bartholomeus is the third son of four brothers who still require fees for schooling. Bartholomeus wants to help the lives of his three brothers. With the Student Loan program of Kiva, he enrolled as a student in AMN because he wants to continue his studies in order to quickly get the job done to help his parents, so that the economy can prosper and so that future parents' lives will be easier. He is very grateful to all lenders of Kiva who have helped in his study, even though they do not know him personally.

loans.use: to pay his education fees for three years.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 38-year-old farmer from Galadima.  As a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim , is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ibrahim can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Ibrahim is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season due to the yield-enhancing inputs that he will access with this loan. When asked how he plans to use the money he will make from selling his produce, Ibrahim said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children; Samsin, Hassan, and  Asabe. Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Yakubu

texts.en: Yakubu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Yakubu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children; Tijjani, Usama,  and  Nasiru. Yakubu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Yakubu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Yakubu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Yakubu said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Yakubu is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Vincentius Priyobudi

texts.en: Commerce management and harbor cruise is the study program selected by Vincentius. Currently, he is a candidate student at the Academy of Maritime Nusantara (AMN). He is eager to work in a shipping company or in a port in Indonesia. Vincentius' parents are very supportive and eager to help Vincentius complete his education. Vincentius' father is just a private employee whose income is uncertain. His mother takes care of the family and does not have any special skills. So, Vincentius' family life is very simple because they only rely on the income from his father. Vincentius still has one brother who also requires school fees.  Vincentius hopes to follow this Student Loan program from Kiva in order to ease the burden on his parents. Vincentius thanks lenders throughout the world, although not personally known. Hopefully, these loans can be very useful for Vincentius and his family.

loans.use: to pay his education fees for three years.

loans.name: Jerose

texts.en:
Jerose is 18 years old and is from Camiling, Tarlac. She has two siblings and their family’s source of income is farming.

She is taking up Food and Beverage Service studies at St. Paul College of Technology. She wants to finish her studies to find a job and help her family. Studying is expensive, so to sustain her studies she wants to borrow a PHP 10,000 loan from KIVA lenders.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees.

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Sheila is 39 years old and is married with one child.  

Sheila and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home was wiped out. She is taking out a housing loan amounting to PHP 9,250 to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family. 

Sheila has been with NWTF borrower since 2012. She plans to recover through her general store business.

With your help, Sheila can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Katon Prasojo

texts.en: Katon is now 19 years old. He is still very young and eager to get ahead in life. He lives in a small village named Kedungreja, on the outskirts of the city of Cilacap. He is the second of two brothers. His sister is in college as well. His parents want all of their children to get an education for their future to be better. The provision of education is the only thing his parents can give, because his parents only work as casual laborers. Their income is uncertain, depending on the presence or absence of a project on which they can get work. Due to the condition of his parents, Katon is motivated to quickly complete college. Currently, Katon is registered as a prospective student at the Academy of Maritime Nusantara (AMN). He takes the program's management and harbor cruise commerce courses. Katon applied for a loan from Kiva to help ease the burden of his parents. Katon also hopes that with this loan, he can quickly get a job as a clerk at a port or shipping company.

loans.use: to pay his education fees for three years

loans.name: Ishaya

texts.en: Ishaya is a 40-year-old farmer from Galadima. As a Babban Gona member, Ishaya is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ishaya can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Ishaya is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Ishaya said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, and in 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Ishaya is on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Rogie Rose

texts.en:
Rogie Rose is 20 years old. She is taking up Food and Beverage Services in St. Paul College of Technology. She wants to finish her studies to find a job and help her family. She also wants to finish college because according to her, it will determine her abilities. 

One of the struggles she faces while studying is payment for her tuition fees. That’s why she wants a loan of PHP 10,000 from KIVA lenders to help her sustain her schooling.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees.

loans.name: Abelita

texts.en:
Abelita is 18 years old and is from Camiling, Tarlac. She is taking up Hotel and Restaurant Services in St. Paul College of Technology. She wants to finish college to have a bright future. Poverty is what drives her to study. 

To be able to support her schooling, she wants to seek financial assistance from the KIVA lenders by availing a loan of PHP 10,000 which she will use to pay for her tuition fees.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees.

loans.name: R-Jay

texts.en:
R-jay is taking up Food and Beverage Services in St. Paul College of Tarlac. He aspires to finish college to be able to help his siblings and mother. 

His family is struggling financially but he won’t let it hinder him to achieve his dreams. So he wants to seek financial assistance from KIVA lenders by availing a loan of PHP 10,000, to help him in paying his tuition fees and other school expenses.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia is 37 years old and lives in Punta, Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She is widowed with three school-aged children.
 
Eugenia earns a living from her monthly pension as a surviving spouse. She receives approximately PHP 3,500.00 each month from her pension. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing construction materials for house repairs. 

Eugenia has been a member of PMPC for almost nine years. In the future, Eugenia hopes to engage in business.

loans.use: to be used in purchasing construction materials for house repairs.

loans.name: Ginalyn

texts.en: Ginalyn is 19 years old and is from Camiling, Tarlac. She is studying Food and Beverage Services in St. Paul College of Technology. She aspires to finish college to be able to help her parents who are working hard as farmers. To do this, she wants to seek financial assistance from KIVA lenders by availing a loan of PHP 10,000 to be used in paying for her tuition fees.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees.

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie is 49 years old and is married with six children. With two children in school, Melanie works very hard to provide for them.

Melanie's business and family home was destroyed by super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013. Melanie has restarted her fish vending business and now needs to provide her family with safe shelter.

Melanie has taken a PHP 7,395 housing loan through NWTF in order to purchase materials to rebuild her family home. She is using the this loan purchase building materials and pay for construction labor. Melanie is committed to rebuild her devastated life and in future would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Kornelis

texts.en: Kornelis originates from a mountainous area, specifically Flores in eastern Indonesia. He travels alone and leaves his parents to study commerce and harbor administration management at the Academy of Maritime Nusantara (AMN), on the island of Java, in the city of Cilacap. The city of Cilacap is very far away from his native village. The expectation of his parents is that Kornelis can learn diligently and quickly to complete his college education. All efforts were made in order to help but his parents are just ordinary farmers in his village. Money from farm sales is to provide for the family and for the school fees for the other two children. If the weather is bad, his parents can not get the  maximum results, Kornelis is very upset with the condition of his parents an, he is determined to quickly complete his studies. He hopes, with a loan from Kiva lenders, he can help overcome these difficulties. Kornelis hopes to quickly get a job in a shipping company.

loans.use: to pay his education fees for three years.

loans.name: Idang Aria

texts.en: Idang is a prospective student at the Academy of Maritime Nusantara (AMN).  He wants to get into the management and harbor administration commerce program because he wants to work in a large port. Idang lives in a rural area, in a low-lying area, precisely in the area of Purbalingga, Central Java. His parents have a fish pond open for business, the income of which is uncertain. Parents have only enough revenue to finance the family's daily life, Idang has two siblings who are still in need of funds for their education. Idang is eager to his help parents to progress to the lives of his family and two siblings. With the Student Loan program of Kiva in AMN through Social Development Welfare Foundation, he wants to pursue his studies and to completed them quickly n order to quickly get the job done. He is very grateful to all investors of Kiva, who help in his study, even though they do not know him personally.

loans.use: to pay his education fees for three years

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is 19 years old, and is taking up studies in Food and Beverage Services at the St. Paul College of Technology. Her mother is a single parent whose income is from farming. Being a single parent with seven children is hard especially in terms of finances. To help her mother, Evelyn would like to take out a loan of PHP 10,000 from KIVA lenders which she will use to pay her tuition fee.

loans.use: to pay her tuition fee

loans.name: Rovie

texts.en:
Rovie is 18 years old and is from Camiling, Tarlac. She is taking up studies in Hotel and Restaurant Services. She has five siblings and their family’s source of income is through her father who works as a driver. 

Rovie wants to finish her studies because she believes that it is very important and she wants to help her family. She chose this course because she wants to express her cooking skills. To pursue her dreams and finish college, she would like to take out a loan of PHP 10,000 from KIVA lenders which she will use to pay her tuition fee.

loans.use: to pay her tuition fee

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en:
Shazia is a 40-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a business of flower making for the last ten years. She offers various colorful flowers for decorating homes and events like birthdays, parties etc. She sells them to the people of her community and also supplies in the local market. She has good communication skills and has a good client list. 

Her husband works as a laborer and earns insufficient income to support her family alone. Shazia is motivated to provide for her family. She wants to grow her business so she requested a loan of PKR 45,000 to buy raw materials such as glace papers, shinning papers, glues and floral tapes. In this way she would be able to meet with the increasing demands of her customers consistently.  She is in her sixth loan cycle with good credit history.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as glace papers, shinning papers, glues and floral tapes.

loans.name: Lynnie

texts.en:
Lynnie is 20 years of age, and is taking up studies in Food and Beverage Services at the St. Paul College of Technology. She wants to finish college to get a job and help send her younger sibling to school. 

Although sometimes Lynnie has insufficient money, she still wants to pursue her schooling. To help her in her studies, she is seeking financial assistance from KIVA lenders by taking out a loan of PHP 10,000.

loans.use: to pay her tuition fee

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf is a farmer from Ba'awa. As a Babban Gona member, Yusuf is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yusuf can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yusuf is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Yusuf said “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family, in 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Yusuf is on his way to achieving this dream

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Khatuna

texts.en:
Khatuna is 26 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and an infant child in a small village in Akhmeta district, Kakheti region, East Georgia. Khatuna is now pregnant and is expecting her second child. Her husband runs an agricultural business. In particular, they have a plot of agricultural land where they cultivate the land and grow vegetables to sell locally. The income is seasonal and is not enough for the family. 

Khatuna decided to request a loan and purchase pigs. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to receive a loan of 300 GEL to purchase pigs. The family has gathered some money and they only need 300 GEL to add to this money to purchase pigs. They will raise and resell pigs at a higher price to improve the living conditions for their family of four. Khatuna awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase pigs to raise and resell

loans.name: Sahib  Khatoon

texts.en:
Sahib Khatoon is a 53-year-old married woman and a mother of two children. In order to earn income for her family, she began a general store about five years ago. Her husband (also shown in the picture) also assists her. Her main aim for starting this business was to provide a good education and food for her family. 

The store provides all kinds household items of daily needs required by the people of her area. She has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR which she intends to purchase stock of rice, oil, candies, biscuits, beverages etc. to satisfy her customers’ increasing demands. Her dream is to afford a good life for her family.

She is in her seventh loan cycle with Kashf foundation.

loans.use: to purchase stock of rice, oil, candies, biscuits, beverages etc.

loans.name: Matha

texts.en: Matha is a 25-year-old farmer from Chiroma.  As a Babban Gona member, Matha is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Matha can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Matha is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, she will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of 35 bags of maize per hectare.  Matha is hopeful about what the future holds; she  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, she will finally be able to afford to educate her children; Isti,  Elkana,  and  Absalom.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield
